content.statement: aku-f03-bekenstein-hawking-entropy is a fundamental concept in Natural-Sciences Physics Quantum-Mechanics Planck-Units that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-f03-bekenstein-hawking-entropy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-f03-bekenstein-hawking-entropy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-f03-bekenstein-hawking-entropy.

full_form.description: Black hole entropy in terms of horizon area A

planck_units_form.description: Entropy as area in Planck units
planck_units_form.interpretation: Entropy is k_B times number of Planck areas divided by 4

natural_units_form.interpretation: Entropy in nats is area divided by 4 Planck areas

information_form.interpretation: One bit per (4 ln(2) ≈ 2.77) Planck areas

area_law.statement: Black hole entropy is proportional to surface area, not volume
area_law.significance: This is profoundly different from ordinary matter, where entropy ~ volume
area_law.implication: Suggests fundamental bound on information density in any region
area_law.holographic_principle: Maximum entropy in region ~ surface area of boundary in Planck units

contrast_ordinary_matter.black_hole: S ~ A ~ R² (for horizon radius R)
contrast_ordinary_matter.ratio: S_BH / S_ordinary ~ (R/ℓₚ)² / (R/λ)³ = (λ/ℓₚ)² · (λ/R) where λ is molecular size

hawking_temperature.significance: Black holes emit thermal radiation at this temperature
hawking_temperature.relation_to_entropy: T_H = (∂M/∂S)_A using first law of black hole mechanics

hawking_radiation.description: Black holes emit thermal radiation with temperature T_H
hawking_radiation.spectrum: Perfect blackbody spectrum at temperature T_H
hawking_radiation.interpretation: Smaller black holes evaporate faster and are hotter

entropy.description: Bekenstein-Hawking entropy for Schwarzschild black hole

solar_mass_black_hole.evaporation_time: τ ≈ 2.1 × 10⁶⁷ years (much longer than age of universe)
solar_mass_black_hole.interpretation: Stellar-mass black holes are extremely cold and evaporate extremely slowly

primordial_black_hole.interpretation: Small black holes are hot and evaporate in cosmologically short times

planck_mass_black_hole.interpretation: Quantum gravity regime - semiclassical approximation breaks down

holographic_principle.statement: The maximum entropy contained in a region of space is proportional to the area of its boundary (in Planck units), not its volume
holographic_principle.motivation: Black holes have the maximum entropy for a given volume (according to Bekenstein bound)
implications: Universe might be a hologram - 3D physics encoded on 2D boundary
Suggests quantum gravity has fewer degrees of freedom than expected
Connection to AdS/CFT correspondence in string theory

information_paradox.problem: Hawking radiation appears thermal (no information) - but quantum mechanics says information cannot be destroyed
information_paradox.hawking_calculation: Pure quantum state → thermal Hawking radiation (mixed state) violates unitarity
possible_resolutions: Information encoded in subtle correlations in Hawking radiation
Information stored at horizon and released during evaporation
Firewall hypothesis (but may violate equivalence principle)
ER=EPR: entanglement creates wormholes connecting radiation to interior
information_paradox.current_status: Active research area; no consensus resolution yet (as of 2025)
information_paradox.significance: May require revision of either quantum mechanics, general relativity, or both

physical_features.planck_scale_connection: Formula fundamentally involves Planck length via ℓₚ² = ℏG/c³
physical_features.experimental_status: Not directly testable with current technology (black holes too massive and cold)
physical_features.theoretical_status: Well-established from semiclassical quantum field theory in curved spacetime

altLabel.@value: Area Law for Black Hole Entropy

definition.@value: The entropy of a black hole is proportional to the area of its event horizon in Planck units: S_BH = (k_B c³/4ℏG)·A = k_B·A/(4ℓₚ²), representing one bit per ~4 Planck areas

scopeNote.@value: Fundamental result in black hole thermodynamics, quantum gravity, and holography. Bridges quantum mechanics, general relativity, and thermodynamics. Underlies holographic principle.

prerequisites.reason: Formula fundamentally involves Planck area ℓₚ²

prerequisites.title: Planck Area
prerequisites.reason: Formula explicitly uses Planck area A_P = ℓₚ² as unit of entropy: S = k_B A/(4A_P)

prerequisites.title: Schwarzschild Black Holes
prerequisites.reason: Need to understand event horizons and black hole geometry

prerequisites.title: Quantum Field Theory in Curved Spacetime
prerequisites.reason: Hawking's derivation uses QFT in curved spacetime

enables.title: Black Hole Information Paradox
enables.reason: Entropy formula central to information paradox

related.relationship: Planck area A_P = ℓₚ² is the fundamental unit in which entropy is measured
Hawking temperature expressed in terms of Planck temperature
Planck-mass black holes enter quantum gravity regime
Hawking radiation and entropy are intimately connected

skos:related.skos:prefLabel: First Law of Black Hole Mechanics

learning_objectives: Understand the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy formula S = k_B A/(4ℓₚ²)
Recognize the area law: entropy proportional to area, not volume
Calculate black hole entropy, temperature, and evaporation time
Understand the connection to holographic principle
Appreciate the unification of QM, GR, and thermodynamics
Understand the black hole information paradox
common_errors: Thinking entropy is proportional to volume (it's area!)
Confusing Hawking temperature with ordinary temperature (it's geometric)
Forgetting factor of 4 in formula (common mistake)
Thinking stellar-mass black holes evaporate quickly (they're extremely long-lived)
physics_insights: Black holes are the most entropic objects possible - maximum entropy for given volume
Area law suggests our universe might be holographic - 3D physics from 2D information
Hawking radiation connects black holes to thermodynamics and quantum mechanics
Information paradox may require new physics beyond GR and QM
One Planck area stores about 1/4 nat (or about 1/2.77 bit) of information
teaching_tips: Start with thermodynamic analogy: black holes have temperature, entropy, etc.
Emphasize area vs volume - this is the key surprise
Work through solar mass example to show practical calculation
Connect to holographic principle for broader context
Discuss information paradox as motivation for quantum gravity research
